entity1.name: Renewable energy sources
entity1.description: Forms of energy derived from natural processes that are replenished at a faster rate than they are consumed.
entity1.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources1

entity2.name: Climate change
entity2.description: Long-term alteration in Earth's climate and weather patterns, primarily due to human activities such as the emission of greenhouse gases.
entity2.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources1

entity3.name: Fossil fuels
entity3.description: Hydrocarbon-containing materials formed from the remains of ancient plants and animals that can be burned for energy.
entity3.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources1

entity4.name: renewable energy sources
entity4.description: A category of energy resources that are naturally replenished and have a low environmental impact, such as solar, wind, hydro, and geothermal power.
entity4.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources2

entity5.name: sustainable and environmentally friendly energy system
entity5.description: An energy system designed to meet current and future energy needs while minimizing environmental impact and ensuring long-term resource availability.

entity6.name: renewable energy sources
entity6.description: A category of energy resources that are naturally replenished and have a low environmental impact, such as solar, wind, hydro, and geothermal power.

entity7.name: sunlight
entity7.description: Radiant energy from the sun, a primary source of renewable energy.
entity7.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources4

entity8.name: wind
entity8.description: Air in motion caused by uneven heating of the Earth's surface, used to generate electricity through wind turbines.
entity8.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources4

entity9.name: rain
entity9.description: Water falling from clouds as droplets, which can be harnessed for hydroelectric power generation.
entity9.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources4

entity10.name: tides
entity10.description: The rise and fall of sea levels caused by the gravitational pull of the moon and sun, which can be used to generate tidal energy.
entity10.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources4

entity11.name: waves
entity11.description: Movements on the surface of water bodies, often caused by wind, that can be converted into electrical power through wave energy converters.
entity11.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources4

entity12.name: geothermal heat
entity12.description: Thermal energy generated and stored in the Earth, which can be utilized for heating or electricity generation.
entity12.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources4

entity13.name: fossil fuels
entity13.description: A general term for a variety of hydrocarbon-containing materials that can be used as fuel, including coal, oil, and natural gas.
entity13.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources5

entity14.name: renewable energy sources
entity14.description: A category of energy resources that are naturally replenished and have a low environmental impact, such as solar, wind, hydroelectric, biomass, and geothermal power.
entity14.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources6

entity15.name: greenhouse gas emissions
entity15.description: Gases that trap heat in the atmosphere, leading to global warming and climate change. Major greenhouse gases include carbon dioxide, methane, and nitrous oxide.
entity15.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources6

entity16.name: climate change
entity16.description: Long-term alterations in temperature, precipitation, wind patterns, or other elements of the Earth's climate system. It is primarily caused by human activities such as burning fossil fuels and deforestation.
entity16.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources6

entity17.name: energy security
entity17.description: The availability of energy at affordable prices, in sufficient quantities, and with minimal disruption. It involves the reliability of supply, diversity of sources, and sustainability of resources.
entity17.chunkid: The Development of Renewable Energy Sources6

entity18.description: A form of renewable energy derived from the sun's rays, used to generate electricity or heat.

entity19.description: A method of generating electricity by harnessing sunlight.

entity22.description: Devices that convert sunlight into electricity, typically installed on rooftops or in solar farms.

entity26.name: Solar energy
entity26.description: A renewable energy source that harnesses the power of the sun to generate electricity.

entity27.description: The total amount of electrical power required by all sectors globally, including residential, commercial, and industrial uses.

entity28.description: The segment of the economy responsible for the production, distribution, and sale of energy products and services.

entity37.description: An increase in the size of the blades or rotors on a wind turbine to capture more wind energy and improve efficiency.

entity38.description: The construction of higher support structures for wind turbines, allowing them to reach stronger and more consistent winds at greater heights.

entity40.description: Wind energy installations located in bodies of water, typically offering higher wind speeds and less visual impact compared to onshore installations.

entity41.name: renewable energy
entity41.description: A form of energy derived from natural processes that are replenished at a rate that is equal to or faster than its consumption, such as sunlight, wind, and geothermal heat.

entity42.name: onshore wind farms
entity42.description: Wind energy installations located on land, which may have lower wind speeds and more visual impact compared to offshore installations.

entity43.name: Hydropower
entity43.description: A renewable energy source that generates power by using the flow of water.

entity50.name: environmental impacts
entity50.description: Refers to the effects of human activities on the natural environment, including habitat disruption and water scarcity.

entity51.description: The alteration or destruction of habitats that can lead to a loss of biodiversity and ecological imbalance.

entity52.description: A condition where the demand for water exceeds its availability, leading to shortages and potential conflicts over resources.

entity53.description: Hydropower projects that are designed to have a reduced environmental impact by generating electricity on a smaller scale compared to large dams.

entity54.description: A type of hydropower project that uses the natural flow of a river to generate electricity without the need for large reservoirs or significant water storage.

entity55.name: Geothermal energy
entity55.description: A form of renewable energy that harnesses the Earth's internal heat for various applications, including electricity generation and heating systems.

entity56.name: Earth's core
entity56.description: The central part of the Earth, consisting primarily of iron and nickel, which is extremely hot and serves as a heat source for geothermal energy.

entity57.description: Power generation facilities that utilize geothermal energy from underground reservoirs of hot water or steam to produce electricity.

entity82.name: feed-in tariffs
entity82.description: A policy mechanism designed to accelerate investment in renewable energy technologies by offering long-term contracts to renewable energy producers, typically based on the cost of generation of each technology.

entity84.description: A policy that requires utility companies to generate a specified percentage of their electricity from renewable energy sources by a certain date.

entity86.description: Systems that generate energy from naturally replenished resources, such as sunlight, wind, rain, tides, waves, and geothermal heat.
